text.content: old but still goes pretty hard

text.plain_text: old but still goes pretty hard

text.content: went back to classic concept of spidey movie, where a lesson is learned in the hardest way possible. all criticism about how tom holland’s spidey was taken way too far from its nature in the first installment (where he moved on fairly quick and the absent of guilt and morallity regarding to the accident of uncle Ben). it redeemed itself here (better late than never tho). and when it did, emotion is what tingling (wish i could shoot web) in me through out the movie.

text.plain_text: went back to classic concept of spidey movie, where a lesson is learned in the hardest way possible. all criticism about how tom holland’s spidey was taken way too far from its nature in the first installment (where he moved on fairly quick and the absent of guilt and morallity regarding to the accident of uncle Ben). it redeemed itself here (better late than never tho). and when it did, emotion is what tingling (wish i could shoot web) in me through out the movie.

text.content: i was kinda meh on tom holland version but i’m glad this changed my perspective, where seeing his spidey growing into something more mature, it’s super relatable.

text.plain_text: i was kinda meh on tom holland version but i’m glad this changed my perspective, where seeing his spidey growing into something more mature, it’s super relatable.

text.content: the awesomeness is taking to the top when i see all the characters from previous ones coming back. holyf, the nostagia hit me when i see andrew and tobey. they’re all like the definition in their all way but share similarities, then they comes together and it puts a joyful smile on my face 🥲.

text.plain_text: the awesomeness is taking to the top when i see all the characters from previous ones coming back. holyf, the nostagia hit me when i see andrew and tobey. they’re all like the definition in their all way but share similarities, then they comes together and it puts a joyful smile on my face 🥲.

text.content: my go-to superhero movie formula that is always works for me is to give it the “heart” as the center then build upon it. like the old tobey spidey and amazing andrew 1 (and 2 - in some incomplete ways). it’s kinda universal formula for pretty much everything but imo, superhero movies and comicbook movies often get carried away with the grand visual fight scenes and costumes, but lacking or have very weak emotional arch. that’s the reason i started to disengage to MCU a few years ago, i was looking at Avenger 2 and being clueless about every single heroes and villain that come together, fighting the final battle. if the movie must include a bunch of superheroes then, at the minimum work, give the character a solid establishment (a dedicated portion of runtime) to work on first. for this movie, the scene where MCU’s spidey lost his aunt. it’s is heartbreaking but necessary for me as audience can root for him (and 3 of them, cuz the rest need no introduction). i know it’s cliche but whatever, it’s spider-man anyway 🙏. justice league (theatrical cut) from DC was being criticized for striping shiton of effort for making characters’ development in the runtime, resulting in a very fuckup product. Hence the Snyder cut is ranked the superior compared to it, just by putting everything back together in one piece 😂. people went from hating flash for being mousy little shit, hating cyborg for being ‘mechanic’ weirdo and hating batman for being fat useless bitch into loving them all. anyway, i got sidetracked, peace ✌

Hence the Snyder cut is ranked the superior compared to it, just by putting everything back together in one piece 😂. people went from hating flash for being mousy little shit, hating cyborg for being ‘mechanic’ weirdo and hating batman for being fat useless bitch into loving them all. anyway, i got sidetracked, peace ✌
